visuals.title: Ideal Voltage Amplifier Transfer
visuals.description: Linear relationship V_out = A_V × V_in with no saturation or distortion.

visuals.title: Practical Amplifier: Saturation Limits
visuals.description: Real amplifiers clip at ±V_CC. The linear region is bounded by the supply rails.

visuals.title: Input Signal Loss vs R_in/R_S Ratio
visuals.description: As R_in/R_S → ∞, the input voltage divider loss → 0. Need R_in >> R_S for voltage amps.

visuals.title: Output Loss vs R_out/R_L Ratio
visuals.description: For voltage amps: as R_out/R_L → 0, output loss → 0. Smaller R_out is better.

visuals.title: Typical R_in Values by Technology
visuals.description: Op-amps have the highest R_in (10¹² Ω). FETs > BJTs > Power stages.

visuals.title: Typical R_out Values
visuals.description: Emitter follower has the lowest R_out (~10 Ω). CE has moderate R_out.

visuals.title: Gain-Bandwidth Product Tradeoff
visuals.description: Practical amplifiers trade gain for bandwidth. The gain-bandwidth product (GBP) is approximately constant.

visuals.title: Harmonic Distortion: Small vs Large Signal
visuals.description: Small signal operation keeps THD < 1%. Large signal introduces significant distortion.

visuals.title: Impedance Requirements Map
visuals.description: Each amplifier type has specific R_in and R_out requirements for minimal loading.

visuals.title: Class A Efficiency vs Signal Swing
visuals.description: Class A amplifiers have max 25% efficiency for resistive load. Efficiency increases with signal swing but distortion increases too.
